Sunday’ s event officially kicked off at 1 p.m., with approximately 100 motorists...
text:
The Brandon Road Rebels took their Rollin' COVID Appreciation Tour outside the
city last Sunday, hoping to lift the spirits of rural seniors and front-line
workers who are being particularly affected by the coronavirus pandemic.

According to Road Rebels president Dave Burba, this outing was a smashing
success, since more than 150 motorists from all over Westman, including some
participants from Saskatchewan, ended up joining their great big convoy that
travelled through Minnedosa, Neepawa and Carberry.

"It was just awesome to see," Burba said on Tuesday. "Everybody seemed to
really appreciate it; the hospitals, the personal care homes, their service
people, everybody just seemed to just think it was a wonderful idea, and we're
so glad and happy that we could be a part of it."

Burba described this as the largest rural cruise he's seen in western
Manitoba, with only last year's Super Run tour of the Second Chance Car Museum
in Treherne being comparable in terms of scale.

Sunday's event officially kicked off at 1 p.m., with approximately 100
motorists taking off from the Beaver Truck Centre parking lot in Brandon.

From there, the convoy joined up with even more classic car enthusiasts in
Minnedosa and Neepawa, creating a cacophony of old-school engine growls that
drew waves and cheers from nearby spectators.

"It was just a real uplifting event for the town at this time of year with
this COVID-19 that's going on," Minnedosa Valley Cruisers president Don
Morrison said. "It brightened everybody up for a while."

The cruisers also made sure to patronize several local businesses along the
way, pulling up for a tasty treat at Minnedosa's Dari Isle Drive-In and some
soft serve at the Dairy Queen in Neepawa.

Local resident Terry Smith, who was following along in his 1986 Pontiac
Parisienne Brougham, told the Sun the convoy's ice cream pit stop in Neepawa
was a pretty spectacular site, with roughly 123 vehicles snaking around the
restaurant's drive-thru window.

Smith said the Carberry leg of the journey was the absolute highlight of his
day since, in his estimation, close to 60 per cent of the town's population
came out to watch them drive by.

"This is like a dream that I had, and it finally came true," Smith said.
"Every car was so nice and shiny and nobody was hot rodding or spinning tires
or being foolish. And the look on the people's faces when all these cars went
by was happiness in a lot of ways."

Sunday's event was just the latest evolution in the Road Rebels' rollin'
tours, which have replaced their static downtown cruise nights that usually
take place this time of year.

Now, instead of parking their cars in downtown Brandon for an extended period
of time, local motorists are encouraged to drive around a set route and stay
in their vehicles as much as possible to try to maintain social distancing.

The first official rollin' tour took place in Brandon on May 3, and ever since
then, Smith said, he and other other Westman gear heads have embraced the new
format, actually preferring it to what's come before.

"I would sooner go for a cruise than I would sit on the street and have people
look at my car," he said. "And I've talked to four different people from
Neepawa who were involved on Sunday, and they all said that a cruise was more
fun than going to a car show, really."

Brandon car enthusiast Lindsay Rystephanuk expects these rollin' tours will be
the standard event format for Westman car enthusiasts throughout the rest of
the summer, which is just fine by him.

"This COVID thing has really changed the status quo of how we show off our
cars," he said. "It's all different, and I think we're finding a very
successful formula for getting our cars out there and getting the people to
see them."

The Road Rebels' next rollin' tour is scheduled to take place in Brandon on
Father's Day, June 21. Visit the club's official Facebook page for more
information on any upcoming events.

» [kdarbyson@brandonsun.com](mailto:kdarbyson@brandonsun.com)

» Twitter: @KyleDarbyson

title: On the road again
html:
The Brandon Road Rebels took their Rollin’ COVID Appreciation Tour outside the city last Sunday, hoping to lift the spirits of rural seniors and front-line workers who are being particularly affected by the coronavirus pandemic.

According to Road Rebels president Dave Burba, this outing was a smashing success, since more than 150 motorists from all over Westman, including some participants from Saskatchewan, ended up joining their great big convoy that travelled through Minnedosa, Neepawa and Carberry.

“It was just awesome to see,” Burba said on Tuesday. “Everybody seemed to really appreciate it; the hospitals, the personal care homes, their service people, everybody just seemed to just think it was a wonderful idea, and we’re so glad and happy that we could be a part of it.”

Burba described this as the largest rural cruise he’s seen in western Manitoba, with only last year’s Super Run tour of the Second Chance Car Museum in Treherne being comparable in terms of scale.

Sunday’s event officially kicked off at 1 p.m., with approximately 100 motorists taking off from the Beaver Truck Centre parking lot in Brandon.

From there, the convoy joined up with even more classic car enthusiasts in Minnedosa and Neepawa, creating a cacophony of old-school engine growls that drew waves and cheers from nearby spectators.

“It was just a real uplifting event for the town at this time of year with this COVID-19 that’s going on,” Minnedosa Valley Cruisers president Don Morrison said. “It brightened everybody up for a while.”

The cruisers also made sure to patronize several local businesses along the way, pulling up for a tasty treat at Minnedosa’s Dari Isle Drive-In and some soft serve at the Dairy Queen in Neepawa.

Local resident Terry Smith, who was following along in his 1986 Pontiac Parisienne Brougham, told the Sun the convoy’s ice cream pit stop in Neepawa was a pretty spectacular site, with roughly 123 vehicles snaking around the restaurant’s drive-thru window.

Smith said the Carberry leg of the journey was the absolute highlight of his day since, in his estimation, close to 60 per cent of the town’s population came out to watch them drive by.

“This is like a dream that I had, and it finally came true,” Smith said. “Every car was so nice and shiny and nobody was hot rodding or spinning tires or being foolish. And the look on the people’s faces when all these cars went by was happiness in a lot of ways.”

Sunday’s event was just the latest evolution in the Road Rebels’ rollin’ tours, which have replaced their static downtown cruise nights that usually take place this time of year.

Now, instead of parking their cars in downtown Brandon for an extended period of time, local motorists are encouraged to drive around a set route and stay in their vehicles as much as possible to try to maintain social distancing.

The first official rollin’ tour took place in Brandon on May 3, and ever since then, Smith said, he and other other Westman gear heads have embraced the new format, actually preferring it to what’s come before.

“I would sooner go for a cruise than I would sit on the street and have people look at my car,” he said. “And I’ve talked to four different people from Neepawa who were involved on Sunday, and they all said that a cruise was more fun than going to a car show, really.”

Brandon car enthusiast Lindsay Rystephanuk expects these rollin’ tours will be the standard event format for Westman car enthusiasts throughout the rest of the summer, which is just fine by him.

“This COVID thing has really changed the status quo of how we show off our cars,” he said. “It’s all different, and I think we’re finding a very successful formula for getting our cars out there and getting the people to see them.”

The Road Rebels’ next rollin’ tour is scheduled to take place in Brandon on Father’s Day, June 21. Visit the club’s official Facebook page for more information on any upcoming events.
